thread.title: Adelaide’s defensive options strengthened at right time by solving Kyle Cheney’s back problem |
thread.title_full: Adelaide’s defensive options strengthened at right time by solving Kyle Cheney’s back problem | The Advertiser

author: MICHELANGELO RUCCI CHIEF FOOTBALL WRITER
title: Adelaide’s defensive options strengthened at right time by solving Kyle Cheney’s back problem |
text:
ADELAIDE’S defensive options — the key to the Crows’ survival in the hot race to the AFL finals — are peaking at the right time with the end of key defender Kyle Cheney’s nagging back problems.
And Crows defensive coach Darren Milburn also is optimistic with the progress of versatile back man Andy Otten, whose return from repeat knee surgery is tracking perfectly.
Adelaide has survived two major challenges — the Showdown against Port Adelaide last week and the home clash with Gold Coast on Saturday — without club champion and full back Daniel Talia, in the ultimate proof that team defence is solid for the Crows.
Talia missed Saturday’s 45-point win against Gold Coast at Adelaide Oval because of sickness — a virus — rather than a repeat of the concussion that put him out of the derby win against the Power at half-time.
He will resume against Sydney on Saturday at the SCG not only clear of the concussion question, but also rested after a demanding season.
“And that is important given the quality of the opponents coming up (starting with Lance Franklin on Sunday),” Milburn said yesterday.
Cheney and Otten on Sunday continued their build-up to AFL recalls by playing in the SANFL.
Cheney last played on June 27 — in the win against Brisbane at Brisbane, where senior coach Phil Walsh last led the Crows before his death — and has been troubled by a back injury for most the season.
The Crows have finally — after being confused by scans of Cheney’s back — learned the real issue was a bulging disc.
“It’s been ongoing (the back problem) ... it’s troubled (Cheney) since the first part of the year,” Milburn said. “But we’ve finally found out the problem and are treating it better now. It’s a bulging disc and we’ve treated that.”
Otten has not played since August 10 last year, when he was forced to have knee reconstructive surgery. His return to the Adelaide AFL selection mix — while Milburn has novices Jake Lever, Kyle Hartigan and Sam Shaw hold up the Crows defence — only enhances the prospect of interim coach Scott Camporeale building a genuine contender to September when defence counts most.
At 9-6, Adelaide is in total control of its destiny to end a two-season absence from the finals. The equation to September appears to demand the Crows win at least four of its remaining six home-and-away games — and the most challenging are those against Sydney (SCG), Richmond (Adelaide Oval), West Coast (Oval) and in round 23 against Geelong (Kardinia Park).
The question of how Adelaide would cope amid the Walsh tragedy appears answered — and a strong point for considering Camporeale as a contender for the coaching vacancy at West Lakes.
“And that’s been driven by the attitude of the players,” Milburn said yesterday. “That attitude has been especially strong at training — they are working hard.”
Camporeale notes his players have not lost their determination to play in finals — and maximum numbers in training and selection is holding up standards at West Lakes.
“What pleases me the most is the resilience of the group,” Camporeale said while praising the professionalism of his players.
“We’ve just got to try to keep winning to make sure we earn the right to be there at the end of the year. There’s something pretty tasty at the end of the year for them if they want it — that’s what we’re driving for … they want to do something special.
“We’re in total control (of our destiny]). And we’ve got guys coming back. There’s competition for spots.”
THE BIG EQUATION
ADELAIDE’S equation to an AFL finals berth has a return to September guaranteed with four wins from six games.
The run home — Sydney (away), Richmond (home), Essendon (away), Brisbane (home), West Coast (home) and Geelong (away) — has four decisive games.
SYDNEY (SCG)
Not played this year. Crows have lost past three games to Swans — but won past four against Sydney at SCG.
RICHMOND (OVAL)
Not played this year. Crows lost past two to Tigers — including game that cost Brenton Sanderson his security at Adelaide Oval last year.
WEST COAST (OVAL)
Met in Round 15, Crows’ first game after Phil Walsh’s death — and lost by 56 points. Lost past two to Eagles.
GEELONG (KARDINIA)
Game in Round 14 cancelled as Crows mourned Phil Walsh’s death. Crows last won at Geelong in 2003.
